Mental health is a state of mental well-being that enables people to cope with the stresses of life, realize their abilities, learn well and work well, and contribute to their community.
Mental health is more than the absence of mental disorders. Mental health is an integral part of health; indeed, there is no health without mental health.
A supportive mental health environment is one that is conducive to promoting positive mental health and well-being.
Mental health is like physical health, If you need help, then go and ask for it. Most officers say it was the best decision they ever made

patterns: What does it mean to have a mental illness?
responses: Mental illnesses are health conditions that disrupt a person's thoughts, emotions, relationships, and daily functioning.
Most people‚Äôs¬†picture of mentally illness is either a crazy and disillusioned person or they are disoriented and confused but that is often not the case.
Mental illnesses is a health condition that disrupt a person's thoughts, emotions, relationships, and daily functioning and it's associated with distress.
Stress is our body‚Äôs response to pressure.
Many different situations or life events can cause stress. It is often triggered when we experience something new, unexpected or that threatens our sense of self.
Stress can happen when we feel we have little control over a situation.

Anxiety is your body's natural response to stress. It's a feeling of fear about what's to come. But there are ways to overcome it, try taking a walk or counting to 10 slowly.

Depression is a mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.
If you have experienced stress for a long time, this could lead to depression.
It is a mood disorder that involves a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.
Depression is different from the mood fluctuations that people regularly experience

patterns: How does one get mentally ill?
responses: Mental illness has a variety of causes, called risk factors. The more risk factors you have, the more likely you are to develop it. Some examples of risk factors include: Genetics, Living or working in a stressful environment, Childhood trauma, Drugs and Alcohol, Stressful events among many others.
Living in a stressful environment can make you more likely to develop a mental illness.Example: living in poverty, having an abusive family.
Challenges or problems with your mental health can arise from psychological, biological, and social, issues, as well as life events.

responses: Symptoms of Depression include insomnia, restlessness, irritability, reduced interest in activities that are normally pleasurable, fatigue and suicidal thoughts.
Having suicidal thoughts, self-harming or suicidal behaviour, using drugs more than usual are common signs of mental illness
You can't 100% tell someone has depression but you can notice abnormal behaviour in them. They don't have to be out of their mind to show signs of depression.
Difficulty remembering or concentrating on things, difficulty speaking or thinking clearly or making decisions.

You might feel tense or nervous, or like the worst is about to happen.
It might feel harder to enjoy your free time, and it can affect things like your relationships and work.

People often overestimate the negative parts like their own abilities to manage a difficult situation, or the situation itself, and underestimate the positive parts
Your abilities to care for yourself and loved ones, your support networks, and opportunities you come across are some of the positive thing in life
You can find any positive aspects or think of new ways to approach the situation. The opposite of that is bad thinking.
The goal is not to ignore the bad parts of the situation or deny that there's a problem. Instead, reframing your thoughts to make them more productive or hopeful can help you
You can also maintain positive relationships by being aware of feelings and keep control of them when times are tense.
Being grateful is also a great way to keep yourself in a thankful and positive state of mind.

responses: We have protective armour as police, some visible and some not.

The uniforms and badges you wear, the vehicles you drive are all ways of reinforcing a shared identity and purpose. This means you have an active and positive role in the face of trauma exposure which will protect you.
Being able to distance yourself doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre hard hearted and often the emotional impact will come later when you reflect on what happened.
Instead, the ability to focus on the job you must do is an important part of your Protective Armour. You‚Äôre using your brain more than your heart.
Readiness allows you to prepare physically, psychologically, and emotionally and helps you can focus on what you need to do. It doesn't prevent you being affected but it helps.

Feeling competent, acts like a protective shield in the face of trauma exposure. It allows you to retain a sense of control and self-confidence, keeping you active and positive rather than passive and helpless.
In the workplace, when you‚Äôre in a hazardous situation you have confidence in the knowledge and skills of your colleagues.

responses: We have protective armour as police, some visible and some not.

The uniforms and badges you wear, the vehicles you drive are all ways of reinforcing a shared identity and purpose. This means you have an active and positive role in the face of trauma exposure which will protect you.
Remember that you set the one and culture in the workplace and this is especially important when we‚Äôre talking about well-being.
There‚Äôs little point trying to encourage your team to take care of themselves if you‚Äôre not looking after yourself.
If you don‚Äôt take breaks or holidays, and regularly send emails at out of work hours, then your team will feel they need to do the same.
Model the importance of rest and recuperation, both within the working day and outside of work.
Don‚Äôt underestimate the power you have to show by your actions that people are valued and respected.
Giving positive feedback and saying thank you builds individuals' confidence and team loyalty.
Protect time for team activities, both formal meetings and informal coffee breaks.
Mental wellness routines and this informal social support are at the heart of what keeps us well at work.

Just as there are different types of medications for physical illness, different treatment options are available for individuals with mental illness. Treatment works differently for different people. It is important to find what works best for you.
With mental health, recovery means different things to different people. What‚Äôs important is building a meaningful life ‚Äì whatever that means to you.

responses: Since beginning treatment is a big step for individuals and families, and can be very overwhelming.
Since beginning treatment is a big step, it can be very overwhelming. It is important to be as involved and engaged in the treatment process as possible.
Mental illness is treatable with a combination of medication and social support.
Asking your doctor questions concerning your treatment process shows you want to be involved in the treatment.
These treatments are highly effective, with 70-90% of individuals receiving treatment experiencing a reduction in symptoms and an improved quality of life.
With the proper treatment, it is very possible for a person with mental illness to be independent and successful.
When healing from mental illness, early identification and treatment are very important.
The best source of information regarding medications is the physician prescribing them. He or she should be able toexplain everything
Treatment can reduce the distress associated with symptoms and can even help reduce the symptoms themselves. Depending on the person, these therapies may take time (often months) to show benefits
Many people with mental illnesses who are diagnosed and treated respond well, although some might experience a return of symptoms.
For any type of treatment, it is essential that the person affected is proactive and fully involved in the recovery process.
You just need to take the first step and tell a doctor or someone that you want to get better. The rest will come as you go.
